Adam refuses to cast Camilla at her audition, but later the mobsters pressure him to do so, as they remove his line of credit and shut down production. Adam eventually gives in and casts Camilla, which pleases the studio.
Both terms refer to individuals being considered for roles in Adam's film. The difference is that Camilla was ultimately cast, while the identity of the unknown actress remains unclear.
The studio shuts down production after Adam refuses to cast Camilla Rhodes. This action is taken due to pressure from the mobsters.
The mobsters threaten Adam, urging him to cast Camilla Rhodes. They also remove his line of credit, leading to the studio shutting down production.
After Adam discovers his wife's infidelity, she kicks him out of their home. This could potentially lead to a change in the relationship between Adam and his wife's lover.
The cowboy strongly urges Adam to cast Camilla Rhodes, implying a potential association between the two men.
After Rita's name is mentioned by a waitress at Winkie's, she remembers the name Diane Selwyn. They subsequently call her number, but there is no answer.
The casting agent shows Betty around during her audition for a role in Adam's film.
Adam is auditioning for The Sylvia North Story when Betty enters the set. They briefly lock eyes before Betty flees.
A bungling hitman attempts to steal a book of phone numbers, leading to the deaths of three people.
Betty and Rita go to Diane Selwyn's apartment complex, but the occupant explains she is Diane’s neighbor and they recently swapped apartments.
Breaking into Diane's new apartment, Betty and Rita discover a woman’s decomposing corpse, horrifying Rita.
Later that night, the two have sex.
Betty persuades Rita to don a blonde wig similar to Betty’s own hairstyle.
At 2 a.m., Rita awakens from a nightmare while chanting ‘Silencio’ and insists that the two go to Club Silencio.
At Club Silencio, the emcee explains...
... Rebekah del Rio’s Spanish rendition of ‘Crying’...
Discovers a blue box matching the key in her purse,
... Rita vanishes too and the box falls to the floor.
Diane Selwyn, a depressed and struggling actress resembling Betty,
Diane's past relationship with Camilla Rhodes, a successful actress who looks like Rita.
Camilla kisses and whispers about Diane to Adam, angering Diane.
Diane met Camilla on The Sylvia North Story, and they became friends despite Diane losing the leading role to her.
Adam and Camilla prepare to make a joint announcement (suggesting they are getting married).
Diane explains to the partygoers, who all resemble people seen previously, that she moved from Canada after inheriting cash from her aunt.
At Camilla's behest, Diane attends a party at Adam's house on Mulholland Drive.
Diane hires the hitman to kill Camilla and he says that he will leave a blue key to signal completion.
In her apartment, a traumatized Diane stares at the blue key on her coffee table.
At Club Silencio, a blue-haired woman whispers 'Silencio'.

node_1: david lynch's 10 clues to unlocking this thriller
edge: The card titled 'David Lynch's 10 Clues to Unlocking This Thriller' is contained within the original DVD release of the film.
The movie 'Mulholland Drive' has only been given the tagline 'A love story in the city of dreams'
The film 'Mulholland Drive' is directed by David Lynch.
David Sterritt spoke with David Lynch after the film 'Mulholland Drive' screened at Cannes.
The Christian Science Monitor is a newspaper where David Sterritt works as a film critic.
David Lynch's earlier film 'Lost Highway' differs from 'Mulholland Drive' in that the former does not tell a coherent, comprehensible story.
Justin Theroux is an actor who has worked with David Lynch. He stated that David Lynch enjoys it when people interpret 'Mulholland Drive' in bizarre ways.
'Mulholland Drive' is classified as a neo-noir, as are other films.

In the dream interpretation, Betty Elms is portrayed as a successful and charming persona created by Diane Selwyn to reconstruct her past and persona into something like an old Hollywood film. This dream world represents the opposite of Diane's real life where she has failed both personally and professionally.

In her real life, Diane arranges for Camilla, an ex-lover, to be killed. Unable to cope with the guilt, she reimagines Camilla as Rita, a dependent and pliable amnesiac. This action is a clue to her inevitable demise, which continues to appear throughout her dream.
The early interpretation of the film uses dream analysis to explore Diane Selwyn's psyche, suggesting that the first part is a dream of her real self.

Watts said in an interview that she construed Diane as the real character and believed that Betty was the person Diane wanted to be and had dreamed up. This suggests a relationship between Watts, who is an actress, and the character Diane, whom she portrayed in the movie.

Watts's own early experiences in Hollywood parallel those of Diane's. She endured some professional frustration before she became successful, auditioned for parts in which she did not believe, and encountered people who did not follow through with opportunities. This suggests that Watts's personal experiences as an actress are related to the character Betty.

Watts also compared Rita, a character in the movie, with her own experiences in Hollywood. She said that Rita was the damsel in distress and absolutely needed Betty, and that Betty controlled her as if she were a doll. This suggests a relationship between Watts's own experiences and the character Rita.

Wilmington's review of the movie 'Mulholland Drive' suggests a relationship between the director David Lynch, Michael Wilmington as a critic, and the movie itself. Wilmington described everything in the movie as a nightmare, portraying it as a portrayal of the Hollywood golden dream turning rancid, curdling into a poisonous stew of hatred, envy, sleazy compromise, and soul-killing failure.

Wilmington's review also suggests a relationship between Hollywood, the movie 'Mulholland Drive', and the director David Lynch. He portrayed the underbelly of our glamorous fantasies as realistically portrayed in this movie, which is set against the backdrop of Hollywood.

Neil Roberts and Tom Charity suggest that Betty represents Diane's projection of a happier life. This interpretation is also accepted by Roger Ebert and Jonathan Ross, but both are hesitant to overanalyze the film.
Philip French sees Mulholland Drive as an allusion to Hollywood tragedy, but Jane Douglas rejects the theory of Betty's life as Diane's dream.
According to Jonathan Ross, there are storylines in Mulholland Drive that go nowhere and may be the non-sequiturs and subconscious of dreams.
Roger Ebert states that there is no explanation in Mulholland Drive, but there may not even be a mystery.
Lynch's film illustrates the concept of revelatory truth in dreams, highlighting the epistemological uncertainty associated with it.
The portrayal of dreams in Lynch's film explores the uncertain and ambiguous nature of knowledge gained through dreaming.
The monstrous being from the dreams in Lynch's film is discussed by the men at Winkie's, adding to its significance and recurrence throughout the movie.
The monstrous being from the dreams in Lynch's film is associated with the suicide of Diane at the end of the movie, highlighting its ominous and enigmatic nature.
Similarly notes that the images following Diane's apparent suicide undermine the 'dream and reality' interpretation.
Followed by Betty and Rita beaming at each other

node_2: cinematic space that persists after the curtain has dropped on her living consciousness
edge: Notes that 'the ninety-second coda that follows Betty/Diane's suicide is a cinematic space that persists after the curtain has dropped on her living consciousness, and this persistent space is the very theatre where the illusion of illusion is continually unmasked'
Mulholland Drive is a part of the larger body of films directed by David Lynch, commonly referred to as 'Lynch films'.
David Roche is a film theorist who has written about Lynch films.
While Mulholland Drive does have detective story elements, David Roche argues that the films force the audience to become detectives themselves in order to understand the narratives.
In Lynch's films, the spectator is always 'one step behind narration'
Roche argues that Mulholland Drive is a mystery film not because it presents solutions to questions, but because the audience's desire to make sense of it holds the film together.
There are multiple mysteries in the film that ultimately go unanswered by the characters who meet dead ends, like Betty and Rita, or give in to pressures as Adam does.
Roche concludes that Mulholland Drive is a mystery film held together 'by the spectator-detective's desire to make sense' of it.

Despite the proliferation of theories, critics note that no explanation satisfies all of the loose ends and questions that arise from the film. Mulholland Drive has little to do with any single character's love life or professional ambition. The movie is an ever-deepening reflection on the allure of Hollywood and on the multiple role-playing and self-invention that the movie-going experience promises ... What greater power is there than the power to enter and to program the dream life of the culture? What greater power is there than the power to enter and to program the dream life of the culture?' J. When I saw it the first time, I thought it was the story of Hollywood dreams, illusion and obsession. It touches on the idea that nothing is quite as it seems, especially the idea of being a Hollywood movie star.
Do we know who we are? And then I kept seeing different things in it ...

node_2: nothing is quite as it seems
edge: The second and third times I saw it, I thought it dealt with identity. Do we know who we are? And then I kept seeing different things in it ... There's no right or wrong to what someone takes away from it or what they think the film is really about.

It intrigues you. You want to get it, but I don't think it's a movie to be gotten. It's achieved its goal if it makes you ask questions.

node_2: beauty of the world has been cursed
edge: Writer Charles Taylor said, 'Betty and Rita are often framed against darkness so soft and velvety it's like a hovering nimbus, ready to swallow them if they awake from the film's dream. And when they are swallowed, when smoke fills the frame as if the sulfur of hell itself were obscuring our vision, we feel as if not just a romance has been broken, but the beauty of the world has been cursed.'
Lynch inserts queerness in the aesthetic and thematic content of the film.
the non-linear film is 'incapable of sustaining narrative coherence'
lesbianism dissolves the ideological conventions of narrative realism, operating as the switch point for the contesting storyworlds within Lynch's elaborately plotted film'
the presence of mirrors and doppelgangers throughout the film 'are common representations of lesbian desire'
The co-dependency in the relationship between Betty and Rita—which borders on outright obsession—

two similar films, Ingmar Bergman's Persona (1966) and Robert Altman's 3 Women (1977), which also depict identities of vulnerable women that become tangled, interchanging and ultimately merge: 'The female couples also mirror each other, with their mutual interactions conflating hero(ine) worship with same-sex desire'

Lynch pays direct homage to Persona in the scene where Rita dons the blonde wig, styled exactly like Betty's own hair. Rita and Betty then gaze at each other in the mirror 'drawing attention to their physical similarity, linking the sequence to theme of embrace, physical coupling and the idea of merging or doubling'
Mirroring and doubles, which are prominent themes throughout the film, serve to further queer the form and content of the film.

node_2: accused of perpetuating stereotypes and clichés of lesbians, bisexuals, and lesbian relationships
edge: Several theorists have accused Lynch of perpetuating stereotypes and clichés of lesbians, bisexuals, and lesbian relationships.

Rita (the femme fatale) represents two classic stock lesbian characters; Heather Love identifies two key clichés used in the film: "Lynch presents lesbianism in its innocent and expansive form: lesbian desire appears as one big adventure, an entrée into a glamorous and unknown territory".
Rita (the femme fatale) and Betty (the school girl) represent two classic stock lesbian characters;

Simultaneously, he presents the tragic lesbian triangle, "in which an attractive but unavailable woman dumps a less attractive woman who is figured as exclusively lesbian", perpetuating the stereotype of the bisexual "ending up with a man".

For Love, Diane's exclusively lesbian desire is "between success and failure, between sexiness and abjection, even between life and death" if she is rejected. In this context the character of Diane may be interpreted as the "tragic lesbian" cliché pining after the bisexual in the heterosexual relationship.
Love's analysis of the film notes the media's peculiar response to the film's lesbian content: "reviewers rhapsodized in particular and at length about the film's sex".
reviewers rhapsodized in particular and at length about the film's sex scenes, as if there were a contest to see who could enjoy this representation of female same-sex desire the most.

node_2: miscellaneous miscreants who populate the film industry
edge: only character in the second portion of the film whose moral code remains intact

Betty and Rita are two different personas portrayed by Isabelle Huppert in the film. Their relationship is complex, with Betty being haunted by guilt and regret for something she did that led to Rita's suicide. This guilt and moral conditioning eventually lead to Betty's own death.

The illusions presented at Club Silencio in the film seem to have a connection with Betty's moral conditioning and her inner turmoil. This could suggest that Club Silencio might represent some kind of metaphysical space where one can confront their deepest fears.
Camilla appears to have a significant role in Betty's moral conditioning. Her presence seems to weigh heavily on Betty, and her absence might be the reason behind Betty's guilt and regret.

The term 'film industry' refers to the community or group of people working in the film industry. It seems that Betty and Rita are a part of this community, which could have contributed to their complex relationship.

Relationship between Camilla and Diane is one of obsession and frustration for Diane. Camilla becomes a full person after the blue box is opened, symbolizing betrayal, humiliation, and abandonment. Camilla asks for Diane to be present on set where Adam publicly humiliates her with another actor. Rita is seen as a vulnerable representation of Diane's desire for Camilla.

After capitulating and choosing Camilla Rhodes for his film, Adam's cheerful assistant Betty's ability to help Rita comes to an end, placing the blame for her tragedy on the representatives of studio power.
After being stripped of creative control of his film, Adam's personality does not seem to change completely from the first part of the film to the second.
Adam is cuckolded by the pool cleaner played by Billy Ray Cyrus.
After Adam checks into a seedy motel and pays with cash, the manager arrives to tell him that his credit is no good, witnessed by Diane.
Adam is pompous and self-important in the presence of Diane.

In the first part of the film, Coco represents the old guard in Hollywood and welcomes Betty to her wonderful new apartment. This highlights the relationship between established industry figures and up-and-coming actors.

In the second part of the film, Coco appears as Adam's mother and impatiently chastises Diane for being late to the party. This showcases how established figures in the industry may overlook or underestimate newcomers.

Minor characters such as The Cowboy and Camilla Rhodes are involved in pressuring Adam to cast her in his film. This highlights the influence of external parties on creative decisions made by industry professionals.

These characters represent the death of creativity for film scholars and somehow involve themselves in pressuring Adam. This portrays a 'closed hierarchical system' in which ultimate power remains hidden behind a series of representatives.
Minor characters such as Mr. Roque are involved in pressuring Adam to cast Camilla Rhodes in his film. This highlights the pressure that industry professionals may face from external parties.

Originally conceived as a television series by David Lynch for Touchstone Television and intended for the ABC television network. Tony Krantz, responsible for the development of Twin Peaks, was 'fired up' about doing another television series based on Lynch's pitch. The pilot, produced for ABC, featured Rita emerging from a car accident with her purse containing $125,000 in cash and the blue key, and Betty trying to help her figure out who she is. An ABC executive recalled being 'creeped out' by the woman in this horrible crash and asking what happens next. David teased that people were chasing her and that she was trouble, not just 'in' trouble.

Originally conceived as a television series by David Lynch for Touchstone Television and intended for the ABC television network. The pilot, produced for ABC, was watched by an executive who hated it and immediately cancelled it.

Pierre Edleman, Lynch's friend from Paris, came to visit and started talking to him about the film being a feature. Canal+ wanted to give Lynch money to make it into a feature and it took a year to negotiate.
Mulholland Drive began as a 90-minute pilot produced for Touchstone Television and intended for the ABC television network.

Lynch described the attractiveness of the idea of a pilot, despite the knowledge that the medium of television would be constricting:
Lynch: 'I'm a sucker for a continuing story ... Theoretically, you can get a very deep story and you can go so deep and open the world so beautifully, but it takes time to do that.'

In the British Film Institute's 2012 Sight & Sound poll, Mulholland Drive was ranked the 28th greatest film ever made.

Having received 40 critics' votes, it is one of only two films from the 21st century to be included in the list, along with 2000’s In the Mood for Love. The following year, Mulholland Drive was named as the greatest film of the 21st century in a poll conducted by BBC Culture.
